Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a series of conferences designed to foster research and discussion of major issues in macroeconomics and monetary economics that are important for public policy. The conference series has three goals. First, to stimulate new research that develops new models and analyzes economic data. Second, to bring together researchers who approach the science questions in different ways. Third, to develop greater understanding among academic researchers of the multiple factors that influence the formation of economic policy. The conference brings together a diverse audience with the overall goal of encouraging academic researchers to focus on problems that are of importance for policy questions.

The conferences will include research on monetary policy, financial market regulation, income inequality, the New Mercantilism, and demography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Carnegie Rochester NYU Conference organized six conferences, each with six papers and six discussants, covering a range of macroeconomic issues with the objectives of stimulating policy relevance in theoretical and empirical research in economics, encouraging the interchange of ideas among analysts of different approaches, and generating greater understanding by academic economists of practitioners’ environments. In so doing, the project satisfies NSF criteria of intellectual merit and broader impacts.  

The November 2014 conference papers explore how monetary policy and fiscal policy are intertwined as a result of vastly expanded central bank balance sheets, showing: why a central bank needs support for its balance sheet by the fiscal authorities to control inflation; why the Federal Reserve is unlikely to experience large losses or a cessation of remittances to the Treasury; how to construct of a new monetary aggregate that performs well since the early 1980s; why the liquidity premium on government debt implies that inflation can remain low and stable under an indefinite zero interest rate policy; why a run on the central bank’s interest rate target is possible when banks hold large quantities of excess reserves; why the Federal Reserve’s expanded balance sheet policies were associated with higher returns, debt-to-GDP ratios, and fiscal imbalances.    

The April 2015 conference papers explore the dramatic increases in inequality of wealth and income, to understand: the relative effects of reduced tax rates for top income groups, higher income transfers for seniors, and increasing wage dispersion; the so-called “inverse-optimum” method of evaluating the welfare of U.S. tax policy; the sensitivity of fiscal policy effectiveness to credit constraints and to average wealth levels; optimal tax and educational policy; the relationship of fertility choices to inequality; the welfare effects of estate taxation.    

The November 2015 conference papers explore the relationship between politics and financial regulation, covering: the effect of taxation on the decision to take on investment risk; the effects of short-sales restrictions, borrowing leverage constraints, and a transaction tax on asset returns, investment growth, and the equity risk premium; why the median voter supports regulations favoring banks; how banks’ holdings of domestic Sovereign debt help to deter bailouts; why banks that perceive higher regulatory uncertainly (or are more averse to it) reduce lending; why increasing the price of the government’s mortgage guarantee reduces financial fragility.        

The April 2016 conference papers explore the interruption of decades of integration of trade, foreign investment, and financial flows by the financial crisis, to understand: the effect of micro-prudential capital requirements on international bank lending; how financial disintegration in Europe has reduced access to capital and lowered output; why foreign multinationals grew faster than local firms outside of the crisis but slower during the crisis; how specialization in production and fluctuations in trade costs generate boom and bust cycles; the rebalancing from bank loans toward bonds in foreign financing of emerging markets; the linkage in a floating exchange rate regime between monetary policy and regulations that control international capital flows. 

The November 2016 conference papers explore the migration of liquidity creation away from traditional supervised depository institutions, beyond money markets and broker-dealers with bank holding companies, to other non-bank financial entities, to understand: why global investment funded mainly by household saving in the 1980s is now nearly two-thirds funded by corporate saving; how the issuance of bank liabilities provides the economy with insurance and liquidity services; how the interbank network can collapse when regulations designed to keep the market safe are pushed beyond a critical level; that cash hoarding in response to investor redemptions in bond mutual funds is the rule, but that such hoarding has the potential to amplify fire sales and financial fragility; that bonds traded previously by more levered firms were more liquid, but the relationship reversed after the crisis, and that more heavily regulated institutions reduce their intermediation of customer trades.

The April 2017 conference papers ask whether slow growth since the financial crisis can be accounted for by consumers, producers, or governments, to understand: the relationship between innovation, product reallocation, and business cycles; how the zero bound on interest rates can account for slow growth of innovation and productivity; that aging populations combined with increasing life expectancy can help explain slower growth, falling interest rates, and falling productivity growth; that declining firm entry and the aging of incumbent firms imply sluggish U.S. productivity growth; how state-level land-use restrictions have depressed U.S. macroeconomic activity; how political conflict in the U.S. helps explain persistently depressed investment and the slow recovery.
